head.title: Songs in the Musical Interlude and Just in Time11 Published in Columbian Herald and New Daily Advertiser [Charleston, SC] (April 20, 1796), p. 4. The play Just in Time, by Thomas Hurlstone, was first performed at Covent Garden, London, on Oct. 27, 1792, with music by Charles Carter, and received seven further performances during the 1792-93 season. The play was published by J. Debrett, also dated 1792. See The London Stage, 1660-1800, Part 5: 1776-1800, ed. Charles Beecher Hogan, 3 vols. (Carbondale, IL: Southern Illinois University Press, 1968), part 5, vol. 3, p. 1496. No performance in a Charleston theatre is listed in Hoole, Antebellum Charleston Theatre or Sodders, The Theatre Management of Alexandre Placide.

lg.l: Safe from the wreck I’ve reach’d the strand
And hail once more my native land;
Hush’d is the wind, the billows cease
To rage, and all around is peace;
But love within my tortur’d breast
Still rages, and deprives me of my rest.
Though waring elements conspire
To bring me to my heart’s desire,
Though gold I have, enough to bless
The object of my happiness,
If that dear maid is mine no more,
My wealth is useless, and I still am poor.
Of constancy let others boast,
I’ll find a fair on every coast;
And to whatever clime I roam,
I find in every port a home.
Why should I wish at sea to drown,
Because a woman’s fair or brown;
For as they vary like the wind,
I’ll sigh for none but she that’s kind.
Were I but young again, young again, young again,
Were I but young again, hearty and strong,
Oh! How I’d touzle ye, tousle ye, touzle ye,
O how I’d touzle ye all the day long.
The men once told me I was fair,
They prais'd my handsome shape and air,
My cheeks they likn'd to the rose,
That on the sweet briar blushing grows;
My skin like lilies wash’d with dew,
But Ah! I’m one and wrinkled now.
Last night when all were gone to rest
And all the house asleep but me,
Young Edward to my view confest,
Stood as in life he seemed to be:
With many a sigh sore heav'd his breast,
His falling tears I well could see,
And thus his speech to me address’d,
Sweet Susan, wait a week for me!
Although beneath the briney wave,
Even now a lifeless corpse I be;
This proof of love from thee I crave,
This proof O grant, or woe to thee;
For rising from its wary grave,
My injur'd ghost you’ll quickly see,
Thy truth and future peace to save,
O Susan wait a week for me!
At sea when storms begin to rise,
And lightning fires the pole;
When dreadful thunder rends the skies,
And fierce the billows roll;
When nought but horror strikes the view,
I think of home and lovely Sue.
When o’er the deck the waves are borne,
And cables snapt in twain;
When from the yards the sails are torn,
And drench’d amidst the main;
When death in every surge I view,
I think of home and lovely Sue.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: Come ye pow’rs of social glee,
Smile with them and laugh with me;
All your kindest influence shed,
On my Susan and her Ned.
Come, ye pow’rs of social glee.
Laugh with them and smile with me.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: Adieu to sighs, adie to tears,
Sleepless nights and boding fears.
Stormy seas and winds adieu,
All my cares I give to you.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: Poor and ragged stand I here,
Free from Sorrow, love or fear;
Home hath yet no joys for me,
Welcome danger and the sea.
Come ye pow’rs of social glee,
Smile with them and laugh with me.
